title: Possessives

lessonContent.text: In order to indicate the owner of an object or objects, the following possessive adjectives are used. Notice that they agree with the object(s) owned, not the owner:

As you can see, 'your' can be tu(s), su(s) or vuestro(s) depending on whether you are talking to one person or more than one person and whether you would address the person (people) with the familiar tú/vosotros or the formal usted/ustedes, hence:

words2: your friend (talking to one person you know well)
your friends (talking to one person you know well)
your cat (talking to more than one person you know well (i.e. belonging to vosotros)
your house (talking to one person or more than one person you do not know well)
your tickets (talking to one or more than one person you do not know well)

lessonContent.text: There is no problem with tu and vuestro as long as you remember that the possessive adjective must agree in number and gender with the object owned and not the owner, but su can sometimes be ambiguous. Normally, the context makes the meaning clear, but if there is doubt it is possible to clarify the meaning as follows:

words2: your house (when more than one person owns the house)

lessonContent.text: The same applies to 'his', 'her' and 'their', although this is less common as it is usually assumed that su will be third rather than second person unless the context makes it clear that this is not the case:

lessonContentSubCh2.text: If the object that is 'possessed' is omitted, the possessive adjectives described above have to be replaced by 'possessive pronouns' - 'pronouns' because they replace the noun. As with the possessive adjectives, the pronouns must agree in number and gender with the object(s) owned, not with the owner:

words1: Tus zapatos son blancos, los míos son azules
words2: mine (referring to a masculine plural object)
Your shoes are white, mine are blue.

lessonContentSubCh2.text: •The forms of the possessive pronouns are:
As with the possessive adjectives, suyo may be ambiguous and if this is the case it can be replaced by the following:

words1: Mi libro es interesante, pero el de Ud. es aburrido.
words2: My book is interesting, but yours is boring.

words1: Mis libros están aquí, pero los de Ud. están en el coche.
words2: My books are here, but yours are in the car.

label1: el de Uds. | los de Uds.

words1: Mis hermanas viven en Madrid pero las de él no.
words2: My sisters live in Madrid, but his don't.

words1: Mi casa es grande pero la de ella es pequeña.
words2: My house is large, but hers is small.

words1: Mi coche es un Seat pero el de ellos en un Renault.
words2: My car is a Seat but theirs is a Renault.

bContent: La cultura y la historia de Ecuador son tan ricas y diversas como su paisaje, que se caracteriza por sus altas montañas y la selva amazónica. La antigua civilización precolombina de Ecuador se conoce por sus pinturas, esculturas, su cerámica y sus trabajos de orfebrería

Su capital es Quito y el país tiene una población de alrededor de doce millones de personas. La mayor parte de su población es o mestiza o india, con un pequeño porcentaje de descendientes de españoles o africanos.
Ecuador tiene una gran atracción turística por las islas Galápagos, que se conocen en el mundo entero por su belleza y la riqueza natural de su ecosistema y son una reserva natural protegida.
